content: [Page 1] Poisonous Food s While cats don’t beg the same way a dog does, they still can make it clear that they would like a little taste of what we’re eating. Most of the time that is not a good idea. Cats have sensitive digestive systems and if they ea t something they shouldn’t, you will soon see it again. It is better not to give them any of your meal. Some foods are outright poisonous too, such as:  Alcoholic beverages  Apricot and peach pits  Avocado  Cherries - fruit, stones and leaves  Chocolate - all forms  Coffee - all forms  Garlic - all forms  Macadamia nuts  Moldy or spoiled foods  Mushrooms  Onions or onion powder  Products sweetened with xylitol  Raisins and grapes  Salt  Raw potatoes  Yeast dough In addition, ham and pork products, including hot dogs, sausages, lunch meat, bacon or pork chops contain fat globules too big for a cat’s veins and can clog the blood vessels quickly

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
metadata.author: Jennifer Casey

content: . Mineral oil or vegetable oil found in canned tuna and fish products depletes the Vitamin E that is essential to your cat’s well -being. NEVER give your cat aspirin or other human medications without your veterinarian’s instructions. Pet Poison Hotline Call 1 -800-213-6680 or visit www.petpoisonhelpline.com for a 24 -hour helpline staffed by veterinary professionals trained in the field of toxicology. There are many hazards in the home for a cat or kitten, and you should be aware of the following before you turn your new kitty loose

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
metadata.author: Jennifer Casey

content: . www.UnitedAnimalFriends.org Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats [Page 2] Poisonous Plants The following plants are poisonous or hazardous to cats:  Aloe  Amaryllis  Asparagus Fern  Avocado Plant  Azalea  Black Cherry  Bloodroot  Buttercup  Caladium  Castor Bean  Christmas Rose  Clematis  Cycads  Daffodil  Daphne (Laurel)  Delphinium  Dicentra (Bleeding Heart)  Dieffenbachia  Elephant’s Ear  English Ivy  Ferns  Foxglove  Four ‘o Clock  Gladiolus  Golden Pothos  Heavenly Bamboo  Hellebore  Hemlock  Holly  Hyacinth  Hydrangea  Indian Splurge Tree  Iris  Ivy  Jack-in-the-Pulpit  Jerusalem Cherry  Jimson Weed  Lantana (Red Sage)  Larkspur  Lilies  Marijuana  Mistletoe  Morning Glory  Mountain Laurel  Narcissus  Oleander  Philodendron  Poinsettia  Poinciana (Bird of Paradise)  Poison Ivy  Poison Oak  Pokeweed  Rhododendron  Rhubarb Leaves  Sago Palm  Star of Bethlehem  Sweet Pea  Taro Vine  Tomato

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
metadata.author: Jennifer Casey

content:  Philodendron  Poinsettia  Poinciana (Bird of Paradise)  Poison Ivy  Poison Oak  Pokeweed  Rhododendron  Rhubarb Leaves  Sago Palm  Star of Bethlehem  Sweet Pea  Taro Vine  Tomato Plant  Tulip  Wisteria  Yew  Yucca [Page 3] Cat Safety Hazards  Electrical or phone cords or computer cords left dangling  Toilet lids left up

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
metadata.author: Jennifer Casey

content: . A kitten can easily drown in a toilet bowl. The chemicals used in toilets can be poisonous to cats.  Open fire screens  Open Stairways  Reclining chairs and hide -a-beds have mechanisms that can crush a cat or kitten wh o has crawled inside  Fringe or any loose trim. Kittens have strangled when their heads got twisted in the fringe or a hole between trim and fabric.  Dangling drapery or mini -blind cords are another invitation to strangulation  Accessible garbage, especially any kind of bones. Bones can either splinter and perforate the stomach or intestines or form an intestinal blockage

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
metadata.author: Jennifer Casey

content: . Bones can either splinter and perforate the stomach or intestines or form an intestinal blockage.  Needles and/or thread; knitting and/or crocheting materials  Rubber bands, which can wrap around the intestines or cause intestinal blockage  Plastic wrap - a kitten can eat it, strangle on it, or suffocate in it  Plastic bags - a kitten can become trapped and suffocate or get its head tangled in the loop and panic  Styrofoam, especially packing peanuts, which the kitten may eat  Cigarettes  Yarn t oys or feather toys - yarn can come unraveled and wrap around the intestines or block them  Toys with easily removed and swallowed parts  Cellophane - it turns glassy in the stomach and can cause internal lacerations  Christmas tree needles, tinsel and decorations  Open refrigerators, dishwashers, microwaves, ovens, washers and dryers. ALWAYS check for kittens or cats before shutting the door or turning on any appliance

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
metadata.author: Jennifer Casey

content: . ALWAYS check for kittens or cats before shutting the door or turning on any appliance.  Put away feathers and toys attached to ribbon or string, such as kitty teasers, after use.  Kittens and cats will often eat feathers and swallow string. They cannot spit it out because of the barbs on their tongues, which will not allow it.  Keep your workshop off limits. Cats will jump at moving objects such as drills and power saws. They m ay also swallow screws, nails, wire and other small parts.  Kittens like to taste just about everything. Keep all cleaning products and other chemicals stored away and out of reach. Anything with phenyl , such as Lysol (check the label) , is deadly to cats .  Cats love certain scents and one of their favorites is antifreeze, which will kill a cat quickly. If your cat or kitten gets into antifreeze and you discover it in time, RUN to the nearest vet or emergency clinic.

metadata.title: Poisons and Other Hazards for Cats
